summary: HOA decisions are assumed valid unless proven unreasonable by a court.
original_text: An exercise of discretionary authority by a property owners' association concerning a restrictive covenant is presumed reasonable unless the court determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the exercise of discretionary authority was arbitrary, capricious, or discriminatory.

summary: Defines two classes of HOA membership: Class A (standard owners) and Class B (developer).
original_text: The Association shall have two (2) classes of membership, Class 'A' and Class 'B', as more fully set forth in the Declaration and specifically incorporated herein by reference.

summary: Board members are initially appointed by the developer (Class B). After transition, they are elected by owners.
original_text: During the existence of Class 'B' Membership, directors shall be appointed pursuant to the Declaration. Afterward, directors are elected by Class A Members via ballot, proxy, or mail vote.

summary: Board may impose fines and suspend rights for rule violations. Fines become liens and services can be cut off for nonpayment.
original_text: The Board may levy fines, suspend voting rights, and suspend use of amenities for violations of CCRs, Bylaws, or rules. Fines become a lien. Services may be suspended for nonpayment.

summary: HOA will protect directors and officers from liability unless they act with gross negligence or misconduct.
original_text: The Association shall indemnify its officers, directors, and committee members against all claims except those arising from gross negligence or willful misconduct.

summary: Amendments require Board approval and either Class B consent or two-thirds membership vote.
original_text: These By-Laws may be amended only by the affirmative vote or written consent of a majority of the Board and the consent of Class 'B' Members, or two-thirds of combined Class 'A' and 'B' votes present at a meeting.

summary: The official name of the HOA is Plantation Lakes Community Association, Inc.
original_text: The name of the corporation is Plantation Lakes Community Association, Inc.

summary: The HOA is a nonprofit and cannot support political activity or distribute earnings to individuals.
original_text: The Association is a Texas non-profit corporation. No part of the assets or net earnings shall benefit any individual, and no political activity is allowed. Activities must comply with 501(c)(4) IRS code.

summary: The Association's purpose is to enforce CCRs, issue assessments, and promote resident welfare.
original_text: The Association is formed to enforce and administer the Declaration of Covenants, Conditions, and Restrictions for Plantation Lakes. It may fix assessments, enforce restrictions, and promote common benefit.

summary: The HOA can manage finances, collect dues, and enforce liens through legal action.
original_text: The HOA may maintain financial records, monitor agents, and collect assessments. It may send notices and enforce liens via judicial or nonjudicial means.

summary: The HOA may manage property, insure officials, and borrow funds as needed.
original_text: The HOA can insure board members, manage common areas, and borrow money for HOA purposes.

summary: The HOA may hire vendors, enforce ARC guidelines, and maintain adjacent properties.
original_text: The HOA may enter contracts, enforce ARC rules, provide services (e.g., trash), and maintain nearby property.

summary: The HOA may restrict access or voting rights and implement fines for rule violations.
original_text: The HOA may contract with other groups for maintenance, suspend rights for violations, and impose fines.

summary: Amendments to the Articles require a two-thirds vote of members and Declarant approval during Class B control.
original_text: Articles may be amended by a two-thirds vote of members present at a meeting where quorum is reached, with Declarant's consent if applicable.

summary: If the HOA dissolves, its assets must go to a nonprofit or government, not to members.
original_text: If dissolved, assets go to a public body or another nonprofit. Dissolution must follow bylaws and Texas law.

summary: Only specific types of signs are allowed in public view, including one For Sale sign, up to two political signs, and small signs for security or school pride. Builder signs must be ARC-approved.
original_text: No sign or emblem of any kind may be kept or placed upon any Lot or mounted, painted or attached to any Dwelling, fence or other improvement upon such Lot so as to be visible from public view except the following: For Sale signs, political signs, school spirit signs, security system signs, and ARC-approved Builder signs, each with specific size and placement limits.

summary: Accessory structures like sheds, stables, and playhouses require written HOA approval. Rules for size, placement, and design may be set.
original_text: No out building and/or accessory building (including, but not limited to stables, barns, sheds, greenhouses, gazebos, play houses, shade trellis) shall be constructed or placed on a Lot within Plantation Lakes without the prior written approval of the Association. The Association shall have the right without the obligation to promulgate rules, regulations and guidelines regarding the size, quality, location and type of these structures.

summary: Water activities like boating or fishing may be allowed in Plantation Lakes ponds if approved by the Board. Rules may be set.
original_text: Swimming, boating, fishing, canoeing, and kayaking, or other similar activities may be permitted within the ponds, or other bodies of water within Plantation Lakes at the discretion of the Board. The Board of Directors has the right to promulgate rules and regulations governing the use of the ponds and other bodies of water.

summary: All structures must be approved in writing by the HOA or ARC before building or alteration.
original_text: No structure shall be erected, placed or altered on any Lot until the construction plans and specifications, including the plot plan, elevations, and materials have been approved in writing by the Association or the Architectural Review Committee (ARC).

summary: Materials may not be stored on a Lot more than 30 days before building starts. Projects must be completed within 1 year of ARC approval.
original_text: No building materials of any kind shall be placed or stored upon any Lot more than 30 days prior to commencement of construction. All construction must be completed within one (1) year of the ARC‚Äôs approval date unless extended by the ARC.

summary: Driveways must be concrete, asphalt, or another ARC-approved material.
original_text: All driveways must be surfaced with concrete, asphalt or an alternate material approved in writing by the ARC.

summary: Owners must keep their entire Lot clean, including setbacks and easements. The HOA may clean up and bill the owner.
original_text: All portions of each Lot, including setbacks, easements and rights-of-way, shall be maintained by the Owner in a clean and neat condition. The Association may perform cleanup and assess the cost to the Owner.

summary: The HOA can enforce rules through lawsuits, injunctions, or by fixing issues and billing the owner. Costs may become a lien.
original_text: The Association may enforce the provisions of this Declaration by legal proceedings including suit to recover damages, injunctive relief, or any other remedy available under Texas law. The Association may also correct violations and assess costs to the Owner‚Äôs account as a lien.

summary: The HOA may enter a Lot during reasonable times to check for rule compliance, without it being trespassing.
original_text: The Association shall have the right to enter upon any Lot at reasonable times to inspect for compliance with this Declaration. Such entry shall not constitute trespass.

summary: HOA failure to act on a violation does not waive their right to enforce it later.
original_text: If the Association fails to enforce any provision of this Declaration, such failure shall not be deemed a waiver of the right to enforce that provision in the future.

summary: All lot owners must pay annual, special, and specific HOA assessments. These become liens if unpaid.
original_text: Each Owner of a Lot, by acceptance of a deed, is deemed to covenant to pay to the Association annual assessments or charges, special assessments, and specific assessments. These assessments, together with interest, costs, and reasonable attorney  fees, shall be a charge on the Lot and shall be a continuing lien and personal obligation of the Owner.

summary: All new construction must follow these Builder Guidelines and receive ARC approval.
original_text: These guidelines are supplemental to the Declaration... and are to be used in architectural review of Builder, Developer or Owner plans. Non-compliance of these guidelines is grounds for disapproval... All New Construction must be approved by the ARC.

summary: Lot owners are fully responsible for following Builder Guidelines, plats, and local regulations.
original_text: The Property Owner is Solely responsible to develop/maintain individual lots in accordance with... Builder Guidelines, recorded plats, and applicable regulations.

summary: All foundations must be above flood plain and certified by an engineer. Pier & beam must have brick or stone skirting.
original_text: Finished slab elevation... must be above the 100-year flood plain... certified by a qualified Engineer... Pier & Beam foundations require brick/stone skirting.

summary: Fences must be 4‚Äì6 ft, use approved materials, and match design standards. No chain link or barbed wire.
original_text: Conforms to Harmony of Design... approved materials include wood, masonry, vinyl, pipe, wrought iron. Height: 4‚Äì6 ft. Chain link and barbed wire prohibited.

summary: Driveways must be made of concrete or asphalt. ARC may require enhanced designs for visible areas. Culverts must meet county specs.
original_text: Driveways must be concrete or asphalt. Culverts must be installed per County requirements... ARC may require decorative or enhanced driveway surfaces in high-visibility areas.

summary: Garages must fit two full-sized vehicles and be at least 400 sq ft. Detached garages must match the main house in look and materials.
original_text: Garages must be a minimum of 400 sq ft and sized to accommodate at least two full-size vehicles. Detached garages must match the primary residence in design and materials.

summary: Contractors must maintain clean sites or risk fines and stop-work orders. Trash containment is mandatory.
original_text: Contractors must keep construction sites clean and free of debris. Trash must be contained. Failure may result in stop-work orders or fines.

summary: Construction must be completed within 12 months of ARC approval unless extended in writing.
original_text: All new homes or major structures must be completed within twelve (12) months of ARC approval unless otherwise approved in writing.

summary: Lighting must avoid glare. Colored or blinking lights are banned. ARC may apply further restrictions.
original_text: Lighting must be installed to avoid light pollution. No colored or blinking lights allowed. ARC may impose additional restrictions.

summary: Roofs must have a 6:12 pitch or greater. Architectural shingles are required. Alternate materials need ARC approval.
original_text: Minimum 6:12 roof pitch required. Shingles must be high-definition architectural grade or better. Alternative roofing materials must be ARC approved.

summary: Any unlisted project still requires ARC review. The ARC can deny projects that conflict with community standards.
original_text: Any improvement not specifically addressed in these guidelines shall be subject to ARC review and approval. The ARC reserves the right to deny any request that is inconsistent with community character, even if not explicitly prohibited.

summary: The HOA can enforce its rules legally, including using fines and penalties that are set beforehand.
original_text: Article XV Section F of the Declaration provides that the Association shall have the power to enforce the provisions of the Declaration and Rules and Regulations by all lawful means, including levying and collecting reasonable and uniformly applied fines and penalties, established in advance.

summary: The HOA board is officially responsible for enforcing the CCRs.
original_text: The Board of Directors for Plantation Lakes is charged with implementation and enforcement of the CCRs.

summary: Owners have the right to a Board hearing to contest enforcement actions or explain hardships.
original_text: All property owners enjoy the right to a hearing before the Board to challenge most enforcement proceedings and to demonstrate as to why compliance with the CCRs represents a hardship and hinders their full use and enjoyment of their property.

summary: HOA enforcement decisions are presumed fair unless proven otherwise in court.
original_text: An exercise of discretionary authority by a property owners' association concerning a restrictive covenant is presumed reasonable unless the court determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the exercise of discretionary authority was arbitrary, capricious, or discriminatory.

summary: Curable violations go through a staged process of warnings and potential fines or legal action.
original_text: Curable violations follow a process: courtesy letter ‚ 1st 209 letter ‚ 2nd 209 letter ‚Board options (fines, repairs, legal).

summary: Certain violations are uncurable and may result in immediate fines or legal steps if repeated.
original_text: Uncurable violations include fireworks, health threats, noise, damage, or prohibited events and trigger immediate 209 letters and fines/legal action if repeated.

summary: Owners are fined $250 initially and $100 monthly until the issue is resolved.
original_text: Initial Fine: $250.00 per violation if the violation is not cured or reoccurs. Additional Fines: $100.00 per month per violation.

summary: HOA can bill owners for mailing, processing, and attorney fees if legal action is taken.
original_text: Mailing, processing, and legal fees are billed to the property owner and collected like assessments.

summary: The HOA has the legal authority to enforce rules and issue fines under Article XV, Section F.
original_text: WHEREAS, Article XV Section F of the Declaration provides that the Association shall have the power to enforce the provisions of the Declaration and Rules and Regulations by all lawful means, including levying and collecting reasonable and uniformly applied fines and penalties, established in advance.

summary: The Board and ARC enforce CCRs and may interpret unclear rules. Owners can appeal.
original_text: The Board of Directors is charged with implementation and enforcement of the CCRs. The ARC is also authorized to clarify and define ambiguous restrictions. Owners have the right to hearings for enforcement appeals.

summary: The Board has discretion in enforcement unless proven unreasonable in court.
original_text: The Board is authorized to determine the applicability and extent of enforcement. Texas Property Code states that discretion is presumed reasonable unless found arbitrary or discriminatory.

summary: Curable violations follow a 3-step notice process before fines or legal action.
original_text: Steps include courtesy letter, 10-day notice, and 209 letter. If still uncorrected, fines, legal action, or self-help may follow.

summary: Uncurable violations skip early steps and go straight to fines or legal recourse.
original_text: Certain violations are uncurable (e.g., fireworks, landscape damage). They trigger immediate 209 letters and may result in fines, repairs, or legal action.

summary: Violations escalate through levels. Owners may request a hearing. Legal steps follow if unresolved.
original_text: Level 1: Courtesy notice. Level 2-3: Re-inspection and escalation. ARC hearings offered. Noncompliance may lead to legal action or repair at owner‚Äôs expense.

summary: Fines range $250-1,000+, escalate monthly if unresolved. Board can modify them.
original_text: Fines: $1,000 for drainage easement or unapproved ARC project; $500 for ditch issues; $250-10/month for general violations. Board may waive or adjust fines. Legal fees may be charged to owner.

summary: The HOA can legally enforce rules and apply standardized fines and penalties.
original_text: Article XV Section F of the Declaration, provides that the Association shall have the power to enforce the provisions of the Declaration and Rules and Regulations by all lawful means, including levying and collecting reasonable and uniformly applied fines and penalties, established in advance;

summary: The HOA board is responsible for enforcing all CCR provisions.
original_text: The Board of Directors for Plantation Lakes is charged with implementation and enforcement of the CCRs.

summary: Owners can request a Board hearing to challenge enforcement actions or explain hardships.
original_text: All property owners enjoy the right to a hearing before the Board to challenge most enforcement proceedings and to demonstrate as to why compliance with the CCRs represents a hardship and hinders their full use and enjoyment of their property.

summary: HOA rule enforcement decisions are presumed fair unless legally challenged and proven otherwise.
original_text: An exercise of discretionary authority by a property owners' association concerning a restrictive covenant is presumed reasonable unless the court determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the exercise of discretionary authority was arbitrary, capricious, or discriminatory.

summary: Curable violations involve warnings, with escalating actions if not resolved: letters, fines, repairs, or legal steps.
original_text: Curable violations follow a process: courtesy letter ‚1st 209 letter ‚2nd 209 letter ‚Board options (fines, repairs, legal).

summary: Serious violations like fireworks or property damage can be acted on immediately and fined or sent to legal if repeated.
original_text: Uncurable violations include acts like fireworks, safety threats, noise, or damage and may result in immediate fines or legal action if repeated.

summary: Violations move through levels: from courtesy letter to certified warning, and finally legal action or fines.
original_text: Level 1: Initial notice; Level 2‚Äì3: Continued/repeat violations ‚Üí certified notice and hearing option; Level 4: Final step with possible fines, repairs, legal.

summary: Owners are fined $250 initially and $100 monthly until the violation is corrected.
original_text: Initial Fine: $250.00 per violation if the violation is not cured or reoccurs. Additional Fines: $100.00 per month per violation.

summary: The HOA can charge back mailing and legal fees to the owner and collect them like dues.
original_text: Mailing, processing, and attorney fees can be billed to the property owner and collected as assessments.

summary: The Board can choose to reduce or waive fines entirely at their discretion.
original_text: The Board shall have the right, in its sole and absolute discretion, to lower, alter, or waive fines as approved by the Board.
